case_data.name: Doe v. Sylvester
case_data.plaintiff_description: A woman with borderline personality disorder and congenital deafness.
case_data.summary:
On December 15, 1999, a woman with borderline personality disorder and profound congenital deafness filed a lawsuit under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and the Rehabilitation Act against the Secretary of the Delaware Department of Health and Social Services, the Division of Alcoholism, Drug Abuse, and Mental Health in the DHSS, and the Delaware Psychiatric Center, in the United States District Court for the District of Delaware. Plaintiff, represented by Community Legal Aid Society, asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that her rights were violated when an apartment in a community-living facility was not modified to suit her needs. Specifically, the plaintiff claimed that she was confined in an institutional setting longer than necessary because the state did not modify the apartment reserved for her with certain auxiliary aids. Because these modifications were not made, the plaintiff could not live safely in the apartment.

On September 11, 2001, the Court (Judge Roderick R. McKelvie) denied the defendants' motion to dismiss on several grounds. Doe v. Sylvester, 2001 WL 1064810 (D. Del. Sept. 11, 2001).

The complaint was dismissed voluntarily on October 19, 2001. It is unclear whether the plaintiff received relief. The case was closed on October 22, 2001.
case_data.summary_short: This case was brought by a woman with borderline personality disorder and congenital deafness against the Delaware Department of Health and Social Services seeking declaratory injunctive relief to compel Defendant to modify an apartment in a community-living facility to accommodate her deafness.  The case was dismissed voluntarily in October 2001; whether Plaintiff received relief is unclear.
